natural problem:
Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have?
natural solution: Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.

Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$

The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly f (r n) = 0"
and h2 : "card (set (map abs (map r [1..<2007]))) = 1006"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> x. poly f x = 0 \<and> x \<in> Reals} \<ge> 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$
 The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly f (r n) = 0"
and h2 : "card (set (map abs (map r [1..<2007]))) = 1006"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> x. poly f x = 0 \<and> x \<in> Reals} \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A polynomial function $f$ has a degree of $2006$. For every natural number $n \leq 2006$, $f$ evaluated at $r(n)$ equals $0$. Moreover, the cardinality of the set containing the absolute values of $r(n)$ for $n$ ranging from $1$ to $2006$ is $1006$. What is the smallest possible number of real roots that $f$ can have? The final answer is $6$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and roots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "poly_deg f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..2006}. poly f (roots i) = 0"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (roots i)) {1..2006}) = 1006"
shows  "card {i \<in> {1..2006}. roots i \<in> Reals} \<ge> 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$
 The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and roots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "poly_deg f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..2006}. poly f (roots i) = 0"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (roots i)) {1..2006}) = 1006"
shows  "card {i \<in> {1..2006}. roots i \<in> Reals} \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A polynomial function $f$ of degree 2006 has 2006 roots. If the absolute value of these roots are distinct for exactly 1006 of them, find the minimum number of roots that are real numbers. The final answer is 6.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree (poly_lift f) = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..2006} \<longrightarrow> poly (poly_lift f) (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (r i)) {1..2006}) = 1006"
shows  "\<exists>S. S \<subseteq> {1..2006} \<and> card S \<ge> 6 \<and> (\<forall>i\<in>S. r i \<in> Reals)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$
 The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree (poly_lift f) = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..2006} \<longrightarrow> poly (poly_lift f) (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (r i)) {1..2006}) = 1006"
shows  "\<exists>S. S \<subseteq> {1..2006} \<and> card S \<ge> 6 \<and> (\<forall>i\<in>S. r i \<in> Reals)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Let $f$ be a function from the set of real numbers to the set of real numbers and $r$ be a function from the set of natural numbers to the set of real numbers. Assume that the degree of $f$ is 2006. Also, for each natural number $i$ from 1 to 2006, $f$ of $r(i)$ equals 0. Moreover, the number of distinct absolute values of $r(i)$ for $i$ from 1 to 2006 is 1006. Show that there exists a subset $S$ of the set of natural numbers from 1 to 2006, such that the number of elements in $S$ is at least 6, and for every element $i$ in $S$, $r(i)$ is a real number.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree (poly_roots f) = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..2006} \<longrightarrow> f (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (r i)) {1..2006}) = 1006"
shows  "\<exists>S. finite S \<and> card S = 6 \<and> (\<forall>x. x \<in> S \<longrightarrow> f x = 0) \<and> (\<forall>x. x \<in> S \<longrightarrow> x \<in> Reals)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among

 ### Proof

If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$

 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree (poly_roots f) = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..2006} \<longrightarrow> f (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (r i)) {1..2006}) = 1006"
shows  "\<exists>S. finite S \<and> card S = 6 \<and> (\<forall>x. x \<in> S \<longrightarrow> f x = 0) \<and> (\<forall>x. x \<in> S \<longrightarrow> x \<in> Reals)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A real-valued function $f$ has 2006 roots, represented by $r(i)$ for $i$ in the set ${1..2006}$. The absolute values of these roots, when taken as a set, have 1006 unique values. Prove that there exists a set $S$ consisting of 6 real roots of the function $f$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. poly (f x) = 0"
and h1 : "degree (f x) = 2006"
and h2 : "card (range (\<lambda>i. abs (r i))) = 1006"
shows  "card (range (\<lambda>i. r i)) \<ge> 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$

 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. poly (f x) = 0"
and h1 : "degree (f x) = 2006"
and h2 : "card (range (\<lambda>i. abs (r i))) = 1006"
shows  "card (range (\<lambda>i. r i)) \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Suppose there is a polynomial function $f(x)$ of degree 2006 such that for any real number $x$, $f(x)=0$. Now, consider a sequence of real numbers $r(i)$ and denote by $|r(i)|$ the absolute value of each $r(i)$. If the sequence $|r(i)|$ contains 1006 distinct values, then prove that the sequence $r(i)$ must contain at least 6 distinct values.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. poly (f x) r = 0"
and h1 : "degree (f x) = 2006"
and h2 : "card (set (map abs (r ` {1..2006}))) = 1006"
shows  "card {x. poly (f x) r = 0 \<and> x \<in> Reals} \<ge> 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$

 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. poly (f x) r = 0"
and h1 : "degree (f x) = 2006"
and h2 : "card (set (map abs (r ` {1..2006}))) = 1006"
shows  "card {x. poly (f x) r = 0 \<and> x \<in> Reals} \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a polynomial function $f(x)$ of degree 2006 and a sequence $r$ of real numbers such that the polynomial evaluates to zero for every value in the sequence (i.e., $f(r(n)) = 0$ for all $n$), and given that there are 1006 distinct absolute values among the first 2006 values in the sequence, prove that there are at least 6 real roots of the polynomial (i.e., values $x$ for which $f(x) = 0$).

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "polydegree f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> polyroot f (r i)"
and h2 : "card (set (\<lambda>i. abs (r i))) = 1006"
shows  "card (set (\<lambda>i. r i \<in> Reals)) \<ge> 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$
 The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "polydegree f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> polyroot f (r i)"
and h2 : "card (set (\<lambda>i. abs (r i))) = 1006"
shows  "card (set (\<lambda>i. r i \<in> Reals)) \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let $f$ be a polynomial function of degree 2006. Let $r$ be a function from natural numbers to real numbers such that for every natural number $i$ up to 2006, $r(i)$ is a root of $f$. If the cardinality (the number of unique elements) of the set of absolute values of $r(i)$ is 1006, prove that the cardinality of the set of $r(i)$ that are real numbers is at least 6.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "poly_deg f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly_roots f i = r i"
and h2 : "card (image abs (set (map r [1..<2007]))) = 1006"
shows  "card {i. i \<le> 2006 \<and> r i \<in> \<real>} \<ge> 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$
 The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "poly_deg f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly_roots f i = r i"
and h2 : "card (image abs (set (map r [1..<2007]))) = 1006"
shows  "card {i. i \<le> 2006 \<and> r i \<in> \<real>} \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a polynomial function $f$ of degree $2006$. Let $r(i)$ denote the $i$th root of $f$. If there are $1006$ distinct absolute values among the roots of $f$, then there are at least $6$ real roots of $f$ with indices less than or equal to $2006$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "poly_deg f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly_roots f r i"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (r i)) {i. i \<le> 2006}) = 1006"
shows  "card {i. i \<le> 2006 \<and> r i \<ge> 0} \<ge> 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$

 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "poly_deg f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly_roots f r i"
and h2 : "card (image (\<lambda>i. abs (r i)) {i. i \<le> 2006}) = 1006"
shows  "card {i. i \<le> 2006 \<and> r i \<ge> 0} \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Let $f$ be a polynomial of degree 2006, and let $r$ be the function that maps each index $i$ to the $i$th root of $f$. If the absolute values of these roots yield 1006 distinct values, show that at least 6 of these roots are nonnegative.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and S :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "degree f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly f (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "S = { |r i| |i. i \<le> 2006}"
and h3 : "card S = 1006"
shows  "card { i. i \<le> 2006 \<and> r i \<ge> 0} \<ge> 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2006 with real coefficients, and let its roots be $r_1,$ $r_2,$ $\dots,$ $r_{2006}.$  There are exactly 1006 distinct values among
\[|r_1|, |r_2|, \dots, |r_{2006}|.\]What is the minimum number of real roots that $f(x)$ can have? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Since the coefficient of $f(x)$ are real, the nonreal roots of $f(x)$ must come in conjugate pairs. Furthermore, the magnitude of a complex number and its conjugate are always equal. If $n$ is the number of magnitudes $|r_i|$ that correspond to nonreal roots, then $f(x)$ has at least $2n$ nonreal roots, which means it has at most $2006 - 2n$ real roots.
 Also, this leaves $1006 - n$ magnitudes that correspond to real roots, which means that the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n.$  Hence, \[1006 - n \le 2006 - 2n,\]so $n \le 1000.$  Then the number of real roots is at least $1006 - n \ge 6.$
 The monic polynomial with roots $\pm i,$ $\pm 2i,$ $\dots,$ $\pm 1000i,$ 1001, 1002, 1003, 1004, 1005, 1006 satisfies the conditions, and has 6 real roots, so the minimum number of real roots is $\boxed{6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and S :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "degree f = 2006"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> poly f (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "S = { |r i| |i. i \<le> 2006}"
and h3 : "card S = 1006"
shows  "card { i. i \<le> 2006 \<and> r i \<ge> 0} \<ge> 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a polynomial function $f$ of degree 2006. It has 2006 roots denoted by $r_i$ where $i$ ranges from 0 to 2006. Let $S$ be the set of absolute values of these roots. If the cardinality of the set $S$ is 1006, what is the minimum number of roots that are greater than or equal to 0? The final answer is 6.
